scenes.goal: Introduce recursion as a problem-solving technique.
visual_elements: Simple diagram: A function calling itself
scenes.narrative_intent: Define recursion and state its core idea: a function calling itself.

visual_elements: Flowchart: Start -> Check Base Case? -> Yes -> Stop
Text: 'Base Case: The condition that stops recursion'
scenes.narrative_intent: Explain that every recursive function needs a base case to prevent infinite loops.

visual_elements: Flowchart: Check Base Case? -> No -> Perform Action -> Call Function Again
Text: 'Recursive Step: The part that calls the function again'
scenes.narrative_intent: Describe how the function calls itself with modified arguments to progress toward the base case.

visual_elements: Stack diagram: Pushing frames for each call, popping when returning
Animation: Function calls stacking up and unwinding
scenes.narrative_intent: Illustrate how the computer manages recursive calls using the call stack.

scenes.goal: Walk through a classic example: Factorial.
visual_elements: Code snippet: def factorial(n): return 1 if n <= 1 else n * factorial(n-1)
scenes.narrative_intent: Demonstrate recursion with a concrete mathematical example.

visual_elements: Side-by-side: Recursive factorial vs. Iterative factorial (loop)
Pros/Cons list: Readability vs. Memory usage
scenes.narrative_intent: Highlight when recursion is preferable over loops and vice versa.
